elements.content: A new porous coordination polymer (PCP) based on a ligand with a unique bent angle bearing a thiophene-bridged bent carboxylate ligand and the Cu2+ ion was synthesized and structurally characterized. The structure has a pillared-layer framework based on a kagomé-like layer with aromatic partition groups. It exhibits a high CO2 uptake of 180 mL­(STP)/g at 1 bar, and 400 mL­(STP)/g at 30 bar at 273 K. The uptakes of C2H2 and C2H4 reach 164 and 160 mL­(STP)/g at 298 K and 1 bar, with good selectivity of C2H2 and C2H4 over CH4, both of which are among the highest levels of reported PCPs.
elements.clean_text: A new porous coordination polymer (PCP) based on a ligand with a unique bent angle bearing a thiophene-bridged bent carboxylate ligand and the Cu2+ ion was synthesized and structurally characterized. The structure has a pillared-layer framework based on a kagomé-like layer with aromatic partition groups. It exhibits a high CO2 uptake of 180 mL(STP)/g at 1 bar, and 400 mL(STP)/g at 30 bar at 273 K. The uptakes of C2H2 and C2H4 reach 164 and 160 mL(STP)/g at 298 K and 1 bar, with good selectivity of C2H2 and C2H4 over CH4, both of which are among the highest levels of reported PCPs.

elements.content: Porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are crystalline porous materials constructed by organic ligands and metal ions/clusters via coordination bonds. Considering their high porosity and internal surface area, as well as tunable functionality on the pore wall to enhance host–guest interactions, PCPs have shown great promise for gas adsorption and separation. In addition to the tunable pore shapes and sizes, some PCPs possess open metal sites on their secondary building units (SBUs). Because of the strong binding of specific functional groups of molecules, open metal sites are among most powerful ways toward recognition of small molecules. Separation of C2 and C1 hydrocarbons is relatively easy and less focused on among the many combinations of target gases, because of their different molecular sizes and boiling points, yet there is still demand for the improvement of the separation process. The separation efficiencies of C2H4/CH4 and C2H2/CH4 are expected to be greatly enhanced by adsorption separation using PCPs, via the synergy of the confinement effect and the interaction of C–C multiple bonds with open metal sites. One of the well-known SBUs of PCPs is a di-Cu2+ tetracarboxylate cluster complex, also called a paddlewheel unit. The Cu2+ paddlewheel SBU has been widely studied because of its easy fabrication and access to highly porous structures, as well as guest accessible open metal sites, thus realizing a high gas capacity compatible with adsorption selectivity. An extended linker has conventionally been employed to increase the gas adsorption uptake, though it sometimes results in the collapse of the framework upon removal of the guest molecules or the formation of highly interpenetrated structures leading to shrinkage of the pore. Instead of simple extension, ligand desymmetrization had emerged as an alternative way to obtain highly porous structures without using large ligands: For example, the ligand with mixed dicarboxylic and monocarboxylic acid branches and bent angle linker between carboxylic acids. Although so many Cu2+ paddlewheel-based open frameworks have been reported, their separation abilities vary depending on their structures. Thus, the structural influence on gas adsorption selectivity still needs to be disclosed toward gas separation applications. We report a new highly porous PCP based on a Cu2+ paddlewheel SBU, [Cu6(DDC)3(solvent)6] (1; H4DDC = 5,5′-(2,3-dihydrothieno­[3,4-b]­[1,4]­dioxine-5,7-diyl)­diisophthalic acid). The DDC ligand is composed of two isophthalatic acids (ipa) bridged by ethylenedioxythiophene (EDOT). The ipa-EDOT-ipa angle is about 150°, which would not be suitable for highly symmetric periodic structures. Thus, we assumed that the low symmetry of the DDC ligand would provide a rare framework topology. We found that 1 exhibits an uncommon kagomé-like layer with EDOT partition groups, which is also pillared with EDOT spacers. Importantly, 1 has a large surface area, and the uptake of C2 hydrocarbons and the separation factor of C2 over C1 are among the highest levels reported so far.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are crystalline porous materials constructed by organic ligands and metal ions/clusters via coordination bonds. Considering their high porosity and internal surface area, as well as tunable functionality on the pore wall to enhance host-guest interactions, PCPs have shown great promise for gas adsorption and separation. In addition to the tunable pore shapes and sizes, some PCPs possess open metal sites on their secondary building units (SBUs). Because of the strong binding of specific functional groups of molecules, open metal sites are among most powerful ways toward recognition of small molecules. Separation of C2 and C1 hydrocarbons is relatively easy and less focused on among the many combinations of target gases, because of their different molecular sizes and boiling points, yet there is still demand for the improvement of the separation process. The separation efficiencies of C2H4/CH4 and C2H2/CH4 are expected to be greatly enhanced by adsorption separation using PCPs, via the synergy of the confinement effect and the interaction of C-C multiple bonds with open metal sites. One of the well-known SBUs of PCPs is a di-Cu2+ tetracarboxylate cluster complex, also called a paddlewheel unit. The Cu2+ paddlewheel SBU has been widely studied because of its easy fabrication and access to highly porous structures, as well as guest accessible open metal sites, thus realizing a high gas capacity compatible with adsorption selectivity. An extended linker has conventionally been employed to increase the gas adsorption uptake, though it sometimes results in the collapse of the framework upon removal of the guest molecules or the formation of highly interpenetrated structures leading to shrinkage of the pore. Instead of simple extension, ligand desymmetrization had emerged as an alternative way to obtain highly porous structures without using large ligands: For example, the ligand with mixed dicarboxylic and monocarboxylic acid branches and bent angle linker between carboxylic acids. Although so many Cu2+ paddlewheel-based open frameworks have been reported, their separation abilities vary depending on their structures. Thus, the structural influence on gas adsorption selectivity still needs to be disclosed toward gas separation applications. We report a new highly porous PCP based on a Cu2+ paddlewheel SBU, [Cu6(DDC)3(solvent)6] (1; H4DDC = 5,5'-(2,3-dihydrothieno[3,4-b][1,4]dioxine-5,7-diyl)diisophthalic acid). The DDC ligand is composed of two isophthalatic acids (ipa) bridged by ethylenedioxythiophene (EDOT). The ipa-EDOT-ipa angle is about 150°, which would not be suitable for highly symmetric periodic structures. Thus, we assumed that the low symmetry of the DDC ligand would provide a rare framework topology. We found that 1 exhibits an uncommon kagomé-like layer with EDOT partition groups, which is also pillared with EDOT spacers. Importantly, 1 has a large surface area, and the uptake of C2 hydrocarbons and the separation factor of C2 over C1 are among the highest levels reported so far.

elements.content: All commercially available reagents and solvents employed were purchased and used as received without further purification unless otherwise noted. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD) measurement were performed on a Rigaku Saturn 724 diffractometer equipped with a Dectoris PILATUS 200 K detector, using a VariMax Mo Optic with Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71075 Å) and a confocal monochromator. The structure was solved using direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares cycles in SHELX 2014. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined using anisotropic thermal parameters. The guest solvent molecules in the pores were severely disordered and the SQUEEZE command was employed in the refinement. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis was performed on a Rigaku SmartLab X-ray diffractometer using Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) in the 2θ range of 3–40° with a scanning rate of 5° min–1. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a Rigaku Thermo plus EVO2 under a N2 atmosphere with a temperature ramp of 5 °C min–1. Low- and high-pressure gas sorption measurements were performed on Microtrac-BEL BELSORP-max and BEL-HP automated volumetric sorption analyzer respectively, equipped with cryostatic temperature controllers. 1H NMR spectra were measured on a JEOL ECS-400 spectrometer. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were measured on a HITACHI SU-5000 instrument.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instrumentation

All commercially available reagents and solvents employed were purchased and used as received without further purification unless otherwise noted. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD) measurement were performed on a Rigaku Saturn 724 diffractometer equipped with a Dectoris PILATUS 200 K detector, using a VariMax Mo Optic with Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71075 Å) and a confocal monochromator. The structure was solved using direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares cycles in SHELX 2014. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined using anisotropic thermal parameters. The guest solvent molecules in the pores were severely disordered and the SQUEEZE command was employed in the refinement. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis was performed on a Rigaku SmartLab X-ray diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) in the 2θ range of 3-40° with a scanning rate of 5° min-1. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a Rigaku Thermo plus EVO2 under a N2 atmosphere with a temperature ramp of 5 °C min-1. Low- and high-pressure gas sorption measurements were performed on Microtrac-BEL BELSORP-max and BEL-HP automated volumetric sorption analyzer respectively, equipped with cryostatic temperature controllers. 1H NMR spectra were measured on a JEOL ECS-400 spectrometer. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were measured on a HITACHI SU-5000 instrument.

elements.content: A mixture of one drop of Hbf4, 1 Ml solution of 5,5′-(2,3-dihydrothieno­[3,4-b]­[1,4]­dioxine-5,7-diyl)­diisophthalic acid (H4DDC, 47 mg, 0.1 mmol) in 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP, 100 mL) and 1 mL solution of Cu­(NO3)2·2.5H2O (3000 mg, 10 mmol) in water (100 mL) was heated at 80 °C for about 20 d to give green block-shaped crystals.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compound [Cu6(DDC)3(solvent)6]⋅x(solvent) (1)

Synthesis of the Single Crystals of 1 

A mixture of one drop of Hbf4, 1 Ml solution of 5,5'-(2,3-dihydrothieno[3,4-b][1,4]dioxine-5,7-diyl)diisophthalic acid (H4DDC, 47 mg, 0.1 mmol) in 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP, 100 mL) and 1 mL solution of Cu(NO3)2⋅2.5H2O (3000 mg, 10 mmol) in water (100 mL) was heated at 80 °C for about 20 d to give green block-shaped crystals.

elements.content: A mixture of H4DDC (47 mg, 0.1 mmol) in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF, 100 mL) and Cu­(NO3)2·2.5H2O (3000 mg, 10 mmol) in water (100 mL) was heated at 70 °C for several hours to give green rod-shaped crystals (80 mg). The compound was formulated as [Cu6(C22SO10H10)3(DEF)6]·6­(DEF) on the basis of 1H NMR and TGA results.
elements.clean_text:
Bulk Synthesis of 1 

A mixture of H4DDC (47 mg, 0.1 mmol) in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF, 100 mL) and Cu(NO3)2⋅2.5H2O (3000 mg, 10 mmol) in water (100 mL) was heated at 70 °C for several hours to give green rod-shaped crystals (80 mg). The compound was formulated as [Cu6(C22SO10H10)3(DEF)6]⋅6(DEF) on the basis of 1H NMR and TGA results.

elements.content: We synthesized H4DDC ligand via Suzuki coupling from dibromo-EDOT (see the ). The ethylenedioxy group was essential for sufficient solubility of thiophene-based ligand for the synthesis of PCP. Single crystals of 1 suitable for high-quality X-ray diffraction data were obtained solvothermally in the presence of the acid and excess of copper salt. Typical Cu2+ carboxylate PCPs are a blue in color, but the crystals of 1 were green, suggesting the influence of the electron-rich EDOT moiety. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments revealed that 1 crystallized in the orthorhombic space group Cmcm (). In the asymmetric unit, there are half DDC1, one-quarter DDC2 and three Cu2+ ions (). Cu2 and Cu3 are at the 4c position with an occupancy of 25%. All the carboxyl groups are deprotonated in both DDC ligands. Each DDC ligand coordinates to four Cu2+ paddlewheel SBUs and each SBU links to four ligands. The observed ipa-EDOT-ipa angle is 140°, which is slightly smaller than that of the bare DDC ligand, probably due to the confinement effect from the ipa-Cu2+ paddlewheel framework. We note that 1 has the totally different framework structure from those of Cu2+ MOFs based on imidazole or triazole bridged diisophthalate ligand. The fact indicates that the influences of the bent angles and the steric hindrance between the heterocycle and ipa on the structure are quite strong. There are two types of polyhedral cages observed in 1 (a). Cage-A is constructed of four DDC1 ligands, one DDC2 ligand, and five paddlewheel units. Cage-B includes eight DDC1 ligands, five DDC2 ligands, and 11 paddlewheel units. The solvent-accessible volume in 1 is 64.1%, calculated using PLATON with a probe of 1.8 Å, which indicates the presence of potentially large pores for gas sorption.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description of 1 

We synthesized H4DDC ligand via Suzuki coupling from dibromo-EDOT (see the ). The ethylenedioxy group was essential for sufficient solubility of thiophene-based ligand for the synthesis of PCP. Single crystals of 1 suitable for high-quality X-ray diffraction data were obtained solvothermally in the presence of the acid and excess of copper salt. Typical Cu2+ carboxylate PCPs are a blue in color, but the crystals of 1 were green, suggesting the influence of the electron-rich EDOT moiety. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments revealed that 1 crystallized in the orthorhombic space group Cmcm (). In the asymmetric unit, there are half DDC1, one-quarter DDC2 and three Cu2+ ions (). Cu2 and Cu3 are at the 4c position with an occupancy of 25%. All the carboxyl groups are deprotonated in both DDC ligands. Each DDC ligand coordinates to four Cu2+ paddlewheel SBUs and each SBU links to four ligands. The observed ipa-EDOT-ipa angle is 140°, which is slightly smaller than that of the bare DDC ligand, probably due to the confinement effect from the ipa-Cu2+ paddlewheel framework. We note that 1 has the totally different framework structure from those of Cu2+ MOFs based on imidazole or triazole bridged diisophthalate ligand. The fact indicates that the influences of the bent angles and the steric hindrance between the heterocycle and ipa on the structure are quite strong. There are two types of polyhedral cages observed in 1 (a). Cage-A is constructed of four DDC1 ligands, one DDC2 ligand, and five paddlewheel units. Cage-B includes eight DDC1 ligands, five DDC2 ligands, and 11 paddlewheel units. The solvent-accessible volume in 1 is 64.1%, calculated using PLATON with a probe of 1.8 Å, which indicates the presence of potentially large pores for gas sorption.

elements.content: (a) Two types of polyhedral cages observed in 1. (b) Combination of the two types of polyhedral cages. (Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.).
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Two types of polyhedral cages observed in 1. (b) Combination of the two types of polyhedral cages. (Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.).

elements.content: Despite the low symmetry of the ligand, the structure of 1 can be simplified into a typical pillared-layer framework, as the follows (): Each paddlewheel unit is coordinated by four carboxylate groups and each ipa group links two paddle-wheel units. In this way, an infinite kagomé-like layer is formed, which consists of alternating triangle and hexagonal Cu2+ paddlewheel isophthalate rings (a). The EDOT groups of DDC2 divide the large six-membered ring into two small five-membered rings (b). Finally, these wavelike layers packed in opposite directions (d) are linked by the EDOT groups of DDC1 as pillars to form the whole framework (c). On the basis of the above analysis, each DDC ligand can be treated as two 3-connected nodes, and the paddle-wheel units can be considered as 4-connected nodes. Then, 1 exhibits the rare (3,3,4,4)-connected mfj network with a point symbol of (6.72)2(62.72.9.10)2(62.8)4(64.92) (). It is notable that the kagomé-like layer has an irregular shape compared to well-investigated Cu2+ isophthalates (), as seen in other ipa armed PCPs like NOTT-101 in which a p-phenylene spacer was used instead of the EDOT in the DDC ligand. This irregularly shaped kagomé-like layer is a substructure of HKUST-1, but is not common to other frameworks. The characteristic structure probably came from the unique bite angle of the EDOT spacer. As a result of this irregular structure, there is an open metal site rich half-bowl space on the Cage B in a, which might contribute to increase the gas recognition selectivity.
elements.clean_text: Despite the low symmetry of the ligand, the structure of 1 can be simplified into a typical pillared-layer framework, as the follows (): Each paddlewheel unit is coordinated by four carboxylate groups and each ipa group links two paddle-wheel units. In this way, an infinite kagomé-like layer is formed, which consists of alternating triangle and hexagonal Cu2+ paddlewheel isophthalate rings (a). The EDOT groups of DDC2 divide the large six-membered ring into two small five-membered rings (b). Finally, these wavelike layers packed in opposite directions (d) are linked by the EDOT groups of DDC1 as pillars to form the whole framework (c). On the basis of the above analysis, each DDC ligand can be treated as two 3-connected nodes, and the paddle-wheel units can be considered as 4-connected nodes. Then, 1 exhibits the rare (3,3,4,4)-connected mfj network with a point symbol of (6.72)2(62.72.9.10)2(62.8)4(64.92) (). It is notable that the kagomé-like layer has an irregular shape compared to well-investigated Cu2+ isophthalates (), as seen in other ipa armed PCPs like NOTT-101 in which a p-phenylene spacer was used instead of the EDOT in the DDC ligand. This irregularly shaped kagomé-like layer is a substructure of HKUST-1, but is not common to other frameworks. The characteristic structure probably came from the unique bite angle of the EDOT spacer. As a result of this irregular structure, there is an open metal site rich half-bowl space on the Cage B in a, which might contribute to increase the gas recognition selectivity.

elements.content: (a) Kagomé-like layer structure constructed by ipa groups and Cu2 SBUs. (b) Kagomé-like layer constructed by DDC ligands and Cu2+ paddlewheel SBUs in 1. (c) Pillared-layer framework of 1. (d) Packing mode of the kagomé-like layers.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Kagomé-like layer structure constructed by ipa groups and Cu2 SBUs. (b) Kagomé-like layer constructed by DDC ligands and Cu2+ paddlewheel  SBUs in 1. (c) Pillared-layer framework of 1. (d) Packing mode of the kagomé-like layers.

elements.content: We investigated the gas sorption property of 1. Large amount of sample 1 for gas sorption measurements were synthesized by the solvothermal method in DEF. The PXRD pattern of the bulk sample of 1 was totally consistent with the simulated pattern from the SXRD result (), indicating the phase purity of the sample. TGA of the as-prepared 1 shows multiple weight-loss steps ranging from 120 to 230 °C, indicating that the DEF solvents remained both in a channel and on the Cu2+ sites. Because of difficulty in removal of the solvent, we employed solvent exchange with the lower boiling point solvent prior to activation. A freshly prepared sample of 1 was soaked in methanol at room temperature for 3 d. The TGA shows one-step weight loss at 100 °C and then a plateau up to 270 °C, which demonstrates that the DEF molecules were completely replaced by methanol (). The absence of DEF molecules was further confirmed by the 1H NMR spectrum of the digested sample (). We also conducted temperature dependent PXRD measurements to check the stability of 1 upon activation. The PXRD pattern at 150 °C is consistent with that of the as-synthesized pattern, and it did not change after cooling to the room temperature in N2 atmosphere. The result suggests that the framework structure was thermally stable and maintained upon activation, although broadening of some peaks was observed upon exposure to the air (). SEM images of the sample after activation also suggest retention of crystallinity ().
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption Property of 1 

We investigated the gas sorption property of 1. Large amount of sample 1 for gas sorption measurements were synthesized by the solvothermal method in DEF. The PXRD pattern of the bulk sample of 1 was totally consistent with the simulated pattern from the SXRD result (), indicating the phase purity of the sample. TGA of the as-prepared 1 shows multiple weight-loss steps ranging from 120 to 230 °C, indicating that the DEF solvents remained both in a channel and on the Cu2+ sites. Because of difficulty in removal of the solvent, we employed solvent exchange with the lower boiling point solvent prior to activation. A freshly prepared sample of 1 was soaked in methanol at room temperature for 3 d. The TGA shows one-step weight loss at 100 °C and then a plateau up to 270 °C, which demonstrates that the DEF molecules were completely replaced by methanol (). The absence of DEF molecules was further confirmed by the 1H NMR spectrum of the digested sample (). We also conducted temperature dependent PXRD measurements to check the stability of 1 upon activation. The PXRD pattern at 150 °C is consistent with that of the as-synthesized pattern, and it did not change after cooling to the room temperature in N2 atmosphere. The result suggests that the framework structure was thermally stable and maintained upon activation, although broadening of some peaks was observed upon exposure to the air (). SEM images of the sample after activation also suggest retention of crystallinity ().

elements.content: PXRD patterns for 1 in various conditions.
elements.clean_text: 3  PXRD patterns for 1 in various conditions.

elements.content: To check the permanent porosity of 1, we measured the nitrogen sorption isotherm at 77 K. The N2 sorption of 1 (a) exhibits a typical reversible type I isotherm with a saturated adsorption amount of 636 mL­(STP)/g. The large N2 uptake also indicates that the framework was maintained upon activation. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller apparent surface area calculated from the N2 adsorption data is 2410 m2/g, which is similar to that of NOTT-101 (2316 m2/g). Accordingly, the total pore volume is 0.98 cm3/g. Analysis of the N2 adsorption data using the nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) model confirms a narrow distribution of micropores around 10.7 Å, which is consistent with the maximum diameter of Cages A and B. The gas sorption property near ambient temperatures was also studied. As shown in b, c, the CO2 uptake values of 1 are 180 mL­(STP)/g (8.0 mmol/g) at 273 K and 91 mL­(STP)/g (3.7 mmol/g) at 298 K. The adsorbed amount at 273 K is the class of highest value among the reported Cu2+ paddlewheel based PCPs so far (see also ). High-pressure CO2 sorption isotherms shows that maximum uptake increases to exceptionally high values of 400 (44.0%) and 361 mL­(STP)/g (39.3%) under 30 bar at 273 and 298 K, respectively ( and d). Although this CO2 capacity is lower than those of some PCPs with extremely high surface areas such as NU-100 (69.8%, 40 bar at 298 K), it is comparable to those of other highly porous MOFs with open metal sites such as HKUST-1 (35.9%, 15 bar at 298 K), and higher than those of many other famous PCPs with open Cu2+ sites. The coverage dependent isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) for 1 was calculated using the adsorption isotherms collected at 273 and 298 K fitted using the virial equation (see the ). Q st of CO2 adsorption of 1 at zero surface coverage is 24 kJ/mol (e), less than that of HKUST-1 (31.2 kJ/mol), yet comparable to other Cu2+ paddlewheel large pore PCPs such as NOTT-101 (26.5 kJ/mol).

The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller apparent surface area calculated from the N2 adsorption data is 2410 m2/g, which is similar to that of NOTT-101 (2316 m2/g). Accordingly, the total pore volume is 0.98 cm3/g. The coverage dependent isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) for 1 was calculated using the adsorption isotherms collected at 273 and 298 K fitted using the virial equation (see the ). elements.content: (a) N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K (filled symbols, adsorption; open symbols, desorption); inset: pore size distribution analyzed by the NLDFT method. (b) Low-pressure adsorption isotherms at 273 K. (c) Low-pressure adsorption isotherms at 298 K. (d) High-pressure adsorption isotherms at 298 K. The desorption isotherms were identical with the adsorption isotherms and were omitted for b–d. (e) Coverage-dependent isosteric heat of adsorption. (f) IAST predicted selectivity (C2H2:CH4 = 1:1 and C2H4:CH4 = 1:1 mixtures).
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K (filled symbols, adsorption; open symbols, desorption); inset: pore size distribution analyzed by the NLDFT method. (b) Low-pressure adsorption isotherms at 273 K. (c) Low-pressure adsorption isotherms at 298 K. (d) High-pressure adsorption isotherms at 298 K. The desorption isotherms were identical with the adsorption isotherms and were omitted for b-d. (e) Coverage-dependent isosteric heat of adsorption. (f) IAST predicted selectivity (C2H2:CH4 = 1:1 and C2H4:CH4 = 1:1 mixtures).

elements.content: To further evaluate the effect of open metal sites, we examined the sorption property of 1 for CO under ambient conditions. High-pressure adsorption isotherms of CO are shown in d for 298 K and for 273 K. The calculated Q st value at zero coverage is 21 kJ/mol, which is much higher than that of N2 (12 kJ/mol). The heterogeneity factor in the Langmuir–Freundlich fit of the CO adsorption isotherm deviates from 1 (0.85, ). The result indicates that the Cu2+ open metal sites in 1 are active for CO coordination. Q st of CO adsorption of 1 is slightly lower than that of HKUST-1 (27 kJ/mol, see the ), which might be due to the higher electron density at the Cu2+ ions in 1. Actually, theoretically evaluated charges of two of three crystallographically identical Cu2+ in 1, + 1.065 and 1.024 are somehow smaller than the charge of Cu2+ in HKUST-1, + 1.081, which is comparable to the charge of the other Cu2+ in 1 (see the ).
elements.clean_text: To further evaluate the effect of open metal sites, we examined the sorption property of 1 for CO under ambient conditions. High-pressure adsorption isotherms of CO are shown in d for 298 K and  for 273 K. The calculated Q st value at zero coverage is 21 kJ/mol, which is much higher than that of N2 (12 kJ/mol). The heterogeneity factor in the Langmuir-Freundlich fit of the CO adsorption isotherm deviates from 1 (0.85, ). The result indicates that the Cu2+ open metal sites in 1 are active for CO coordination. Q st of CO adsorption of 1 is slightly lower than that of HKUST-1 (27 kJ/mol, see the ), which might be due to the higher electron density at the Cu2+ ions in 1. Actually, theoretically evaluated charges of two of three crystallographically identical Cu2+ in 1, + 1.065 and 1.024 are somehow smaller than the charge of Cu2+ in HKUST-1, + 1.081, which is comparable to the charge of the other Cu2+ in 1 (see the ).

elements.content: The uncoordinated metal sites and the unique cage structure with moderate pores suggest that 1 might be a promising candidate for gas separation. Thus, adsorption experiments of various hydrocarbons were also carried out. At 1 bar, compound 1 exhibits notable adsorption capacities to C2H2 (241 mL­(STP)/g), C2H4 (215 mL­(STP)/g), C2H6 (232 mL­(STP)/g), and CH4 (31 mL­(STP)/g) at 273 K, and C2H2 (164 mL­(STP)/g), C2H4 (160 mL­(STP)/g), C2H6 (156 mL­(STP)/g), and CH4 (18 mL­(STP)/g) at 298 K. The maximum uptake of C2H2 at 298 K ranges from middle to high among this kind of PCPs (e.g., HKUST-1 (201 mL­(STP)/g), NOTT-102 (147 mL­(STP)/g) and PCN-16 (176 mL­(STP)/g)). Q st for C2 hydrocarbons at zero coverage were also calculated as follows: C2H4, 34.7 kJ/mol; C2H2, 33.5 kJ/mol; C2H6, 23.6 kJ/mol CH4, 14.8 kJ/mol (e). Both unsaturated hydrocarbons and CH4 exhibit slightly lower Q st values than those reported (e.g., 39.4 kJ/mol for C2H2 and 18.6 kJ/mol for CH4 in UTSA-50a), as seen in the Q st for CO2 and CO. In order to theoretically estimate interaction energies between the gas molecules with the Cu2+ open metal sites, we conducted density functional theory calculations. The relationship among Q st values for C2 and C1 hydrocarbons (C2H4 ≈ C2H2 > C2H6 > CH4) is consistent with the theoretically calculated binding energies of them with Cu2+ open metal sites. The result further suggests that the gas molecules can interact with open metal sites at low coverage region. (). To estimate the adsorption selectivity of light hydrocarbons, we calculated the Henry’s Law constants, as well as prediction using ideal solution adsorbed theory (IAST) for C2/C1 equimolar binary mixtures at 298 K (f). 1 displays a great separation ratio of C2H2/CH4 = 65.5 at 298 K determined from the Henry’s Law constants. The value of 1 is higher than many other Cu2+ paddlewheel-based PCPs, and comparable to that of UTSA-50a (68.0). Considering that not all Cu2+ paddlewheel PCPs show high C2/C1 ability (), cooperation of open metal sites and size confinement in the irregularly shaped kagomé-like layer structure might be much more compatible for C2H2 and C2H4 than CH4. Moreover, 1 maintains a large adsorption capacity, which may arise from pillaring of the kagomé-like layer with the EDOT groups enlarging the pore volume. Thus, the combination of high selectivity and capacity suggests that 1 is a promising material for the selective adsorptive separation of C2H2 and C2H4 over CH4.

elements.content: We have successfully developed a new highly porous PCP 1 using a tetracarboxylate ligand with a unique bent angle. Because of its open metal sites, irregular cagelike structure, and suitable pore size, 1 exhibits high uptake of CO2 and hydrocarbons and a good selectivity of C2H2 and C2H4 over CH4. These results will offer a new way for the development of cost-effective materials for carbon capture and hydrocarbons separation.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have successfully developed a new highly porous PCP 1 using a tetracarboxylate ligand with a unique bent angle. Because of its open metal sites, irregular cagelike structure, and suitable pore size, 1 exhibits high uptake of CO2 and hydrocarbons and a good selectivity of C2H2 and C2H4 over CH4. These results will offer a new way for the development of cost-effective materials for carbon capture and hydrocarbons separation.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of one drop of Hbf4, 1 Ml solution of 5,5′-(2,3-dihydrothieno­[3,4-b]­[1,4]­dioxine-5,7-diyl)­diisophthalic acid (H4DDC, 47 mg, 0.1 mmol) in 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP, 100 mL) and 1 mL solution of Cu­(NO3)2·2.5H2O (3000 mg, 10 mmol) in water (100 mL) was heated at 80 °C for about 20 d to give green block-shaped crystals.

Bulk Synthesis of <bold>1</bold>

A mixture of H4DDC (47 mg, 0.1 mmol) in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF, 100 mL) and Cu­(NO3)2·2.5H2O (3000 mg, 10 mmol) in water (100 mL) was heated at 70 °C for several hours to give green rod-shaped crystals (80 mg). The compound was formulated as [Cu6(C22SO10H10)3(DEF)6]·6­(DEF) on the basis of 1H NMR and TGA results.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compound [Cu6(DDC)3(solvent)6]⋅x(solvent) (1)

Synthesis of the Single Crystals of 1 

A mixture of one drop of Hbf4, 1 Ml solution of 5,5'-(2,3-dihydrothieno[3,4-b][1,4]dioxine-5,7-diyl)diisophthalic acid (H4DDC, 47 mg, 0.1 mmol) in 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP, 100 mL) and 1 mL solution of Cu(NO3)2⋅2.5H2O (3000 mg, 10 mmol) in water (100 mL) was heated at 80 °C for about 20 d to give green block-shaped crystals.

Bulk Synthesis of 1 

A mixture of H4DDC (47 mg, 0.1 mmol) in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF, 100 mL) and Cu(NO3)2⋅2.5H2O (3000 mg, 10 mmol) in water (100 mL) was heated at 70 °C for several hours to give green rod-shaped crystals (80 mg). The compound was formulated as [Cu6(C22SO10H10)3(DEF)6]⋅6(DEF) on the basis of 1H NMR and TGA results.

cln_elements.content:
A new porous coordination polymer (PCP) based on a ligand with a unique bent angle bearing a thiophene-bridged bent carboxylate ligand and the Cu2+ ion was synthesized and structurally characterized. The structure has a pillared-layer framework based on a kagomé-like layer with aromatic partition groups. It exhibits a high CO2 uptake of 180 mL­(STP)/g at 1 bar, and 400 mL­(STP)/g at 30 bar at 273 K. The uptakes of C2H2 and C2H4 reach 164 and 160 mL­(STP)/g at 298 K and 1 bar, with good selectivity of C2H2 and C2H4 over CH4, both of which are among the highest levels of reported PCPs.

To check the permanent porosity of 1, we measured the nitrogen sorption isotherm at 77 K. The N2 sorption of 1 (a) exhibits a typical reversible type I isotherm with a saturated adsorption amount of 636 mL­(STP)/g. The large N2 uptake also indicates that the framework was maintained upon activation. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller apparent surface area calculated from the N2 adsorption data is 2410 m2/g, which is similar to that of NOTT-101 (2316 m2/g). Accordingly, the total pore volume is 0.98 cm3/g. Analysis of the N2 adsorption data using the nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) model confirms a narrow distribution of micropores around 10.7 Å, which is consistent with the maximum diameter of Cages A and B. The gas sorption property near ambient temperatures was also studied. As shown in b, c, the CO2 uptake values of 1 are 180 mL­(STP)/g (8.0 mmol/g) at 273 K and 91 mL­(STP)/g (3.7 mmol/g) at 298 K. The adsorbed amount at 273 K is the class of highest value among the reported Cu2+ paddlewheel based PCPs so far (see also ). High-pressure CO2 sorption isotherms shows that maximum uptake increases to exceptionally high values of 400 (44.0%) and 361 mL­(STP)/g (39.3%) under 30 bar at 273 and 298 K, respectively ( and d). Although this CO2 capacity is lower than those of some PCPs with extremely high surface areas such as NU-100 (69.8%, 40 bar at 298 K), it is comparable to those of other highly porous MOFs with open metal sites such as HKUST-1 (35.9%, 15 bar at 298 K), and higher than those of many other famous PCPs with open Cu2+ sites. The coverage dependent isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) for 1 was calculated using the adsorption isotherms collected at 273 and 298 K fitted using the virial equation (see the ). Q st of CO2 adsorption of 1 at zero surface coverage is 24 kJ/mol (e), less than that of HKUST-1 (31.2 kJ/mol), yet comparable to other Cu2+ paddlewheel large pore PCPs such as NOTT-101 (26.5 kJ/mol).

The uncoordinated metal sites and the unique cage structure with moderate pores suggest that 1 might be a promising candidate for gas separation. Thus, adsorption experiments of various hydrocarbons were also carried out. At 1 bar, compound 1 exhibits notable adsorption capacities to C2H2 (241 mL­(STP)/g), C2H4 (215 mL­(STP)/g), C2H6 (232 mL­(STP)/g), and CH4 (31 mL­(STP)/g) at 273 K, and C2H2 (164 mL­(STP)/g), C2H4 (160 mL­(STP)/g), C2H6 (156 mL­(STP)/g), and CH4 (18 mL­(STP)/g) at 298 K. The maximum uptake of C2H2 at 298 K ranges from middle to high among this kind of PCPs (e.g., HKUST-1 (201 mL­(STP)/g), NOTT-102 (147 mL­(STP)/g) and PCN-16 (176 mL­(STP)/g)). Q st for C2 hydrocarbons at zero coverage were also calculated as follows: C2H4, 34.7 kJ/mol; C2H2, 33.5 kJ/mol; C2H6, 23.6 kJ/mol CH4, 14.8 kJ/mol (e). Both unsaturated hydrocarbons and CH4 exhibit slightly lower Q st values than those reported (e.g., 39.4 kJ/mol for C2H2 and 18.6 kJ/mol for CH4 in UTSA-50a), as seen in the Q st for CO2 and CO. In order to theoretically estimate interaction energies between the gas molecules with the Cu2+ open metal sites, we conducted density functional theory calculations. The relationship among Q st values for C2 and C1 hydrocarbons (C2H4 ≈ C2H2 > C2H6 > CH4) is consistent with the theoretically calculated binding energies of them with Cu2+ open metal sites. The result further suggests that the gas molecules can interact with open metal sites at low coverage region. (). To estimate the adsorption selectivity of light hydrocarbons, we calculated the Henry’s Law constants, as well as prediction using ideal solution adsorbed theory (IAST) for C2/C1 equimolar binary mixtures at 298 K (f). 1 displays a great separation ratio of C2H2/CH4 = 65.5 at 298 K determined from the Henry’s Law constants. The value of 1 is higher than many other Cu2+ paddlewheel-based PCPs, and comparable to that of UTSA-50a (68.0). Considering that not all Cu2+ paddlewheel PCPs show high C2/C1 ability (), cooperation of open metal sites and size confinement in the irregularly shaped kagomé-like layer structure might be much more compatible for C2H2 and C2H4 than CH4. Moreover, 1 maintains a large adsorption capacity, which may arise from pillaring of the kagomé-like layer with the EDOT groups enlarging the pore volume. Thus, the combination of high selectivity and capacity suggests that 1 is a promising material for the selective adsorptive separation of C2H2 and C2H4 over CH4.
cln_elements.clean_text:
A new porous coordination polymer (PCP) based on a ligand with a unique bent angle bearing a thiophene-bridged bent carboxylate ligand and the Cu2+ ion was synthesized and structurally characterized. The structure has a pillared-layer framework based on a kagomé-like layer with aromatic partition groups. It exhibits a high CO2 uptake of 180 mL(STP)/g at 1 bar, and 400 mL(STP)/g at 30 bar at 273 K. The uptakes of C2H2 and C2H4 reach 164 and 160 mL(STP)/g at 298 K and 1 bar, with good selectivity of C2H2 and C2H4 over CH4, both of which are among the highest levels of reported PCPs.

To check the permanent porosity of 1, we measured the nitrogen sorption isotherm at 77 K. The N2 sorption of 1 (a) exhibits a typical reversible type I isotherm with a saturated adsorption amount of 636 mL(STP)/g. The large N2 uptake also indicates that the framework was maintained upon activation. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller apparent surface area calculated from the N2 adsorption data is 2410 m2/g, which is similar to that of NOTT-101 (2316 m2/g). Accordingly, the total pore volume is 0.98 cm3/g. Analysis of the N2 adsorption data using the nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) model confirms a narrow distribution of micropores around 10.7 Å, which is consistent with the maximum diameter of Cages A and B. The gas sorption property near ambient temperatures was also studied. As shown in b, c, the CO2 uptake values of 1 are 180 mL(STP)/g (8.0 mmol/g) at 273 K and 91 mL(STP)/g (3.7 mmol/g) at 298 K. The adsorbed amount at 273 K is the class of highest value among the reported Cu2+ paddlewheel based PCPs so far (see also ). High-pressure CO2 sorption isotherms shows that maximum uptake increases to exceptionally high values of 400 (44.0%) and 361 mL(STP)/g (39.3%) under 30 bar at 273 and 298 K, respectively ( and d). Although this CO2 capacity is lower than those of some PCPs with extremely high surface areas such as NU-100 (69.8%, 40 bar at 298 K), it is comparable to those of other highly porous MOFs with open metal sites such as HKUST-1 (35.9%, 15 bar at 298 K), and higher than those of many other famous PCPs with open Cu2+ sites. The coverage dependent isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) for 1 was calculated using the adsorption isotherms collected at 273 and 298 K fitted using the virial equation (see the ). Q st of CO2 adsorption of 1 at zero surface coverage is 24 kJ/mol (e), less than that of HKUST-1 (31.2 kJ/mol), yet comparable to other Cu2+ paddlewheel large pore PCPs such as NOTT-101 (26.5 kJ/mol). 

The uncoordinated metal sites and the unique cage structure with moderate pores suggest that 1 might be a promising candidate for gas separation. Thus, adsorption experiments of various hydrocarbons were also carried out. At 1 bar, compound 1 exhibits notable adsorption capacities to C2H2 (241 mL(STP)/g), C2H4 (215 mL(STP)/g), C2H6 (232 mL(STP)/g), and CH4 (31 mL(STP)/g) at 273 K, and C2H2 (164 mL(STP)/g), C2H4 (160 mL(STP)/g), C2H6 (156 mL(STP)/g), and CH4 (18 mL(STP)/g) at 298 K. The maximum uptake of C2H2 at 298 K ranges from middle to high among this kind of PCPs (e.g., HKUST-1 (201 mL(STP)/g), NOTT-102 (147 mL(STP)/g) and PCN-16 (176 mL(STP)/g)). Q st for C2 hydrocarbons at zero coverage were also calculated as follows: C2H4, 34.7 kJ/mol; C2H2, 33.5 kJ/mol; C2H6, 23.6 kJ/mol CH4, 14.8 kJ/mol (e). Both unsaturated hydrocarbons and CH4 exhibit slightly lower Q st values than those reported (e.g., 39.4 kJ/mol for C2H2 and 18.6 kJ/mol for CH4 in UTSA-50a), as seen in the Q st for CO2 and CO. In order to theoretically estimate interaction energies between the gas molecules with the Cu2+ open metal sites, we conducted density functional theory calculations. The relationship among Q st values for C2 and C1 hydrocarbons (C2H4 ~ C2H2 > C2H6 > CH4) is consistent with the theoretically calculated binding energies of them with Cu2+ open metal sites. The result further suggests that the gas molecules can interact with open metal sites at low coverage region. (). To estimate the adsorption selectivity of light hydrocarbons, we calculated the Henry's Law constants, as well as prediction using ideal solution adsorbed theory (IAST) for C2/C1 equimolar binary mixtures at 298 K (f). 1 displays a great separation ratio of C2H2/CH4 = 65.5 at 298 K determined from the Henry's Law constants. The value of 1 is higher than many other Cu2+ paddlewheel-based PCPs, and comparable to that of UTSA-50a (68.0). Considering that not all Cu2+ paddlewheel PCPs show high C2/C1 ability (), cooperation of open metal sites and size confinement in the irregularly shaped kagomé-like layer structure might be much more compatible for C2H2 and C2H4 than CH4. Moreover, 1 maintains a large adsorption capacity, which may arise from pillaring of the kagomé-like layer with the EDOT groups enlarging the pore volume. Thus, the combination of high selectivity and capacity suggests that 1 is a promising material for the selective adsorptive separation of C2H2 and C2H4 over CH4.

metadata.title:
Development
of a Porous Coordination Polymer with a High Gas Capacity Using a
Thiophene-Based Bent Tetracarboxylate Ligand
